content:
Let us assume we have an adjunction F⊣GF \dashv GF⊣G where F:C→DF: C \to DF:C→D and G:D→CG: D \to CG:D→C. Then, for each object c∈Cc \in Cc∈C and object d∈Dd \in Dd∈D we have an isomorphism in Set\mathsf{Set}Set: D(Fc,d)≅C(c,Gd)D(Fc, d) \cong C(c, Gd)D(Fc,d)≅C(c,Gd).

Our adjunction has already told us about some structure in CCC in terms of structure in DDD. That is, we have learned that the set C(c,Gd)C(c,Gd)C(c,Gd) of morphisms from ccc to GdGdGd in CCC is isomorphic to the set D(Fc,d)D(Fc, d)D(Fc,d).

I'm wondering if in some cases we can get more structure on the data of CCC from structure in DDD. For example, consider the case where d=F(c)d = F(c)d=F(c). Then we have an isomorphism in Set\mathsf{Set}Set: D(Fc,Fc)≅C(c,GFc)D(Fc, Fc) \cong C(c, GFc)D(Fc,Fc)≅C(c,GFc). I notice in this case that D(Fc,Fc)D(Fc,Fc)D(Fc,Fc) supports more structure than that of a set. That is, D(Fc,Fc)D(Fc,Fc)D(Fc,Fc) can be turned into a monoid by using composition of the endomorphisms of FcFcFc.

I am curious if this monoid structure can be transported across the adjunction. To compose g:c→GFcg: c \to GFcg:c→GFc after f:c→GFcf: c \to GFcf:c→GFc we could maybe use this process:

  • start with f:c→GFcf: c \to GFcf:c→GFc and g:c→GFcg: c \to GFcg:c→GFc
  • move each of them across the adjunction bijection to get f♯:Fc→Fcf^\sharp: Fc \to Fcf♯:Fc→Fc and and g♯:Fc→Fcg^\sharp: Fc \to Fcg♯:Fc→Fc
  • compose g♯g^\sharpg♯ after f♯f^\sharpf♯, getting g♯∘f♯:Fc→Fcg^\sharp \circ f^\sharp: Fc \to Fcg♯∘f♯:Fc→Fc
  • move this back across the adjunction, getting (g♯∘f♯)♭:c→GFc(g^\sharp \circ f^\sharp)^\flat: c \to GFc(g♯∘f♯)♭:c→GFc

(Here ♯:C(c,GFc)≅D(Fc,Fc)\sharp: C(c, GFc) \cong D(Fc, Fc)♯:C(c,GFc)≅D(Fc,Fc) and ♭:D(Fc,Fc)≅C(c,GFc)\flat: D(Fc, Fc) \cong C(c, GFc)♭:D(Fc,Fc)≅C(c,GFc) are inverse functions in Set\mathsf{Set}Set).

Do we actually get a monoid on C(c,GFc)C(c, GFc)C(c,GFc) in this way using the monoid structure on D(Fc,Fc)D(Fc,Fc)D(Fc,Fc)? I think we have an identity element, given by 1Fc♭:c→GFc1_{Fc}^\flat: c \to GFc1Fc♭​:c→GFc.

Note that for any f:c→GFcf: c \to GFcf:c→GFc, f∘1Fc♭=(f♯∘(1Fc♭)♯)♭=(f♯∘1Fc)♭=(f♯)♭=ff \circ 1_{Fc}^\flat =( f^\sharp \circ (1_{Fc}^\flat)^\sharp)^\flat = (f^\sharp \circ 1_{Fc})^\flat = (f^\sharp)^\flat=ff∘1Fc♭​=(f♯∘(1Fc♭​)♯)♭=(f♯∘1Fc​)♭=(f♯)♭=f. We use the fact that ♯\sharp♯ and ♭\flat♭ are inverse functions in the last step.

We still need to check composition is associative. That is, do we have (g∘f)∘h=g∘(f∘h)(g \circ f) \circ h = g \circ (f \circ h)(g∘f)∘h=g∘(f∘h) for arbitrary g,f,h:c→GFcg,f,h:c \to GFcg,f,h:c→GFc?

  • (g∘f)∘h=(((g♯∘f♯)♭)♯∘h♯)♭(g \circ f) \circ h = (((g^\sharp \circ f^\sharp)^\flat)^\sharp \circ h^\sharp)^\flat(g∘f)∘h=(((g♯∘f♯)♭)♯∘h♯)♭ . Noting that ♯\sharp♯ and ♭\flat♭ are inverse functions, this simplifies to: (g♯∘f♯∘h♯)♭(g^\sharp \circ f^\sharp \circ h^\sharp)^\flat(g♯∘f♯∘h♯)♭
  • g∘(f∘h)=(g♯∘((f♯∘h♯)♭)♯)♭g \circ (f \circ h) = (g^\sharp \circ ((f^\sharp \circ h^\sharp)^\flat)^\sharp)^\flatg∘(f∘h)=(g♯∘((f♯∘h♯)♭)♯)♭ . Noting that ♯\sharp♯ and ♭\flat♭ are inverse functions, this simplifies to: (g♯∘f♯∘h♯)♭(g^\sharp \circ f^\sharp \circ h^\sharp)^\flat(g♯∘f♯∘h♯)♭ .
  • We conclude that composition is associative.

So, I think that the monoid structure on D(Fc,Fc)D(Fc, Fc)D(Fc,Fc) induces a monoid structure on C(c,GFc)C(c, GFc)C(c,GFc), thanks to our adjunction.

I'm curious if this can be generalized. Consider again a bijection provided by our adjunction: D(Fc,d)≅C(c,Gd)D(Fc, d) \cong C(c, Gd)D(Fc,d)≅C(c,Gd). Let us imagine the case where D=AbD = \mathsf{Ab}D=Ab, the category of commutative groups, and where C=SetC = \mathsf{Set}C=Set. We can take F:Set→AbF: \mathsf{Set} \to \mathsf{Ab}F:Set→Ab to be the functor that sends a set to the free commutative group on that set, and G:Ab→SetG: \mathsf{Ab} \to \mathsf{Set}G:Ab→Set to be the forgetful functor the sends a commutative group to its underlying set.

In this setting, our adjunction tells us Ab(Fc,d)≅Set(c,Gd)\mathsf{Ab}(Fc, d) \cong \mathsf{Set}(c, Gd)Ab(Fc,d)≅Set(c,Gd). Now, the category Ab\mathsf{Ab}Ab is special in that every hom-set is also a commutative group. Can we use a similar procedure as described above to induce a commutative group structure on Set(c,Gd)\mathsf{Set}(c, Gd)Set(c,Gd)?

More generally, for an adjunction F⊣GF \dashv GF⊣G with F:C→DF: C \to DF:C→D and G:D→CG: D \to CG:D→C, if the hom-sets in DDD have some additional structure, when can that additional structure be transferred to the corresponding hom-sets in CCC?

I have only a few seconds to write this down, but in this regard, you might enjoy reading up on the Kleisli category construction, specifically composition of Kleisli morphisms, which is closely connected to what you're bringing up.

Another quick comment is that all mathematical structure can be transported across any isomorphism. So if you have an isomorphism X≅YX\cong YX≅Y and XXX has some structure, whether it's a monoid or an abelian group or a topological space or what-have you, then you can transport it across that isomorphism to give YYY the same structure. In particular, therefore, you can do this when XXX and YYY are hom-sets and the isomorphism comes from an adjunction.
